Few scattered punctate foci of T2 hyperintense signal abnormality seen throughout the juxtacortical white matter of the frontal lobes that are nonspecific. The left hippocampus appears subtly T2 hyperintense with slight ill definition of internal architecture and equivocal diminution in volume. There is no intracranial hemorrhage, restricted diffusion, extra-axial fluid collection, mass effect, or midline shift. The corpus callosum, brainstem and cerebellum are normal. The bilobed pituitary gland is normal. Ventricle size and shape are normal. The visualized portions of the orbits are unremarkable. There is mild mucosal thickening throughout the paranasal sinuses. The mastoid air cells and middle ear cavities are clear. Flow-related enhancement in the anterior and posterior circulation is normal, without evidence of intracranial arterial stenosis or occlusion. No aneurysm is identified, allowing for the known limited sensitivity of MRA for a small (<4mm) aneurysm. There may be a small fenestration of the proximal basilar artery.

MR BRAIN W/O & W CONTRAST 7/6/2015 10:17 AM History: Seizure. Unspecified epilepsy without mention of intractable Comparison: None. Technique: Multiplanar T1-weighted, axial fat-saturated T2 FLAIR, and axial susceptibility weighted images of the brain were obtained without the administration of intravenous contrast. Additional precontrast thin section coronal oblique T2-weighted and T2 FLAlR images were obtained through the temporal lobes. After the administration of intravenous contrast, axial diffusion weighted, axial fat saturated T2 FLAIR, and coronal T1-weighted images of the brain were obtained. Contrast: 10 cc Gadavist There is no mass effect, midline shift, or evidence of intracranial hemorrhage. The ventricles are not enlarged out of proportion to the cerebral sulci. Scattered white matter FLAIR hyperintensities compatible with chronic small vessel ischemic disease. Punctate foci of increased susceptibility in the right frontal lobe. In the same region there is subtle abnormal FLAIR hyper-intensity along the superior frontal sulcus, more conspicuous on the post-contrast FLAIR images. Postcontrast images demonstrate no abnormal intracranial enhancing lesions. No abnormal signal or atrophy in the mesial temporal lobes bilaterally. No abnormality of the skull marrow signal is noted. The major vascular intracranial flow-voids are present. The orbits, visualized portions of paranasal sinuses, and mastoid air cells are relatively clear. 1. Punctate foci of increased susceptibility in the right frontal lobe with subtle associated abnormal FLAlR hyper-intensity along the superior frontal sulcus which is of indeterminate significance and may relate to prior trauma. Correlation with EEG may be helpful, as clinically indicated. 2. Medial temporal lobes appear normal.

Following the intravenous administration of contrast, axial, sagittal, and coronal T1 weighted images were obtained. FINDINGS: The precontrast studies demonstrate that there is a 4 mm focus of high T1 and low T2 signal located in the left temporal occipital junction, exhibiting darks signal on the gradient echo images and diffusion-weighted images. This corresponds to a small focal area of calcification seen on a prior head CT dated 4/10/14. Following contrast administration, there is no discernible abnormal enhancement. A second separate 4 mm focus of abnormal nodular enhancement is identified immediately posterior to the first high Tl signal abnormality. The coronal FLAIR and T2-weighted images demonstrate that the adjacent gray matter is abnormally enlarged with relative sparing of the adjacent white matter with faint high T2 signal. This gyral swelling is nonspecific and diagnostic considerations include post-ictal changes. The ventricular system and subarachnoid spaces are normal for age. The diffusion weighted images demonstrate no acute/subacute infarct. The posterior fosse structures including the brainstem appear well preserved. The mastoid air cells and paranasal sinuses are clear. Two very small foci of abnormal signal intensity are identified in the left temporal-occipital junction, as noted above. High Tl signal of the more anterior lesion is compatible with dystrophic calcification with or without prior hemorrhage. The second more posterior one exhibits abnormal enhancement Diagnostic considerations include a cavernous angioma although a neoplastic process such as an oligodendroglioma cannot be fully ruled out. Abnormal high T2 signal with swelling is identified involving the adjacent gyri with relative sparing of the white matter. This may simply represent post ictal change, however neoplastic infiltration may present with a similar appearance.

No appreciable skull thickening or enlargement of the paranasal sinuses. MRI Brain Technique: MR imaging of the brain was performed before and after contrast administration. IV Contrast: 7.5 ML Gadavist. Clinical information: 345.40 LOCALIZATION-RELATED (FOCAL) (PARTIAL) EPILEPSY AND EPILEPTIC SYNDROMES WITH COMPLEX PARTIAL SEIZURES WITHOUT MENTION OF INTRACTABLE EPILEPSU. Comparison: None. There is mild atrophy/volume loss of the cortex with fairly diffusely within the inferior right frontal lobe with a prominent amount of cortical volume loss in the peri-insular region of the right hemisphere. There is secondary enlargement of the right sylvian fissure. There is no appreciable hyperintense T2 signal in the immediate vicinity of the volume loss. There is possible subtle T2 hyperintense signals along the anterior aspect of the right caudate head. The globus pallidus has prominent dark signal on T2-weighted images bilaterally and symmetrically. The hippocampi appear normal and symmetric bilaterally. There is no restricted diffusion or pathologic intracranial enhancement. The major intracranial arterial flow voids appear normal. No appreciable skull thickening or enlargement of the paranasal sinuses. Fairly prominent cortical volume loss in the inferior right frontal lobe and peri-insular region of the right hemisphere with little if any associated T2 hyperintense signal. Differential considerations include previous ischemic insult with encephalomalacia (somewhat unlikely given the lack of associated gliosis), Dyke-Davidoff-Masson syndrome (although there is no appreciable skull thickening or paranasal sinus enlargement), and Rasmussen encephalitis. The diffuse bilateral symmetric T2 dark globus pallidus signal may may be within normal limits, although the possibility of a metal deposition disease is raised by this particular finding.
